instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3332: What is 820-3332? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.ISL6259: What is ISL6259? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2010 through 2015.
definitions.R7021: What is R7021? Current sense resistor between charger current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H around 4v, quarter fan spin, or battery not charging..
definitions.R7022: What is R7022? Current sense resistor between charger current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H around 4v, quarter fan spin, or battery not charging..
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fails ASD -- ID0R & IG3C?
threads.message:
Had this board repaired and sold, but it was returned because it had "no video". I installed it back into the test case and video is working fine, but it does fail ASD in a few tests:

ID0R and IG3C sensor tests both fail with the failure listed as sensors reading below the "low" limit. I know that OS ASD can give a lot of false positives, but it fails reliably each time, and other boards don't have that particular failure ever, so I think it might actually be an issue with the board. Of course, we have our share of buyers/customers who return items claiming they don't work simply because they're too ashamed to admit they ordered the wrong part, or that it did not resolve their issue(s).

Anyway, was just curious what the thoughts were on these two failed sensor tests. Is there anything I could check, or would those sensors be directly related to the PCH on the board? Thanks in advance, as always.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fails ASD -- ID0R & IG3C?
threads.message: For IG3C: water damage or knocked parts around <CHIP>U8350</CHIP> or UD280??  ID0R could be crap under SMC or a bad ISL

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fails ASD -- ID0R & IG3C?
threads.message:
Thanks, Aprendiz!

This unit had no liquid at all; I pulled it fresh from a unit that had video issues (resolved that issue). I inspected the board for missing components and didn't see any, so I replaced UD280 and that resolved the IG3C issue (passes now). The ID0R issue is still occurring, though; before I reflow or pull the SMC--is there anything else I should check besides the SMC, since the unit had no liquid damage? <RESISTOR>R5441</RESISTOR> reads properly.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fails ASD -- ID0R & IG3C?
threads.message: It could be <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP> too, replace that first.......

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fails ASD -- ID0R & IG3C?
threads.message: Oops--I totally missed you mentioning the ISL in the first post, sorry about that. Yes, I'll replace the ISL first to be safe, then will look at the SMC. I'll update tomorrow! :) Thanks, Aprendiz!

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fails ASD -- ID0R & IG3C?
threads.message: Pretty sure this was liquid. ID0R will probably be bad <RESISTOR>R7021</RESISTOR>/22 or traces to the ISL.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fails ASD -- ID0R & IG3C?
threads.message:
You guys nailed; thanks Duke--it was <RESISTOR>R7021</RESISTOR>/<RESISTOR>R7022</RESISTOR>, both were out of spec (one 30ohm and one 980ohm). I replaced both and all is well. I don't see any signs of liquid anywhere on the board, but of course that doesn't mean much. In any event, all seems well now. Thanks guys!

EDIT: I have a few questions, actually, if you don't mind Duke: (1) Is there a place in the schematics where ID0R is related to <RESISTOR>R7021</RESISTOR>/<RESISTOR>R7022</RESISTOR>? I searched the schematics prior to posting, and didn't see anything directly related between ID0R and <RESISTOR>R7021</RESISTOR>/22. In other words, how would someone know to check those resistors? Is it just from knowing and experience? Also, this board was one that was sold by us (passed ASD perfectly), then returned with these faults. Do these 2 things sound like something that could have resulted or popped up due to using a bad/cheap charger? Something obviously blew those 2 resistors in the time the customer had the board. I'm just curious, so I can learn a bit and know for the future. Thank you again, Duke--always masterful assistance. Also, thank you so much Aprendiz--you've helped me dozens of times.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fails ASD -- ID0R & IG3C?
threads.message:
Yes those resistors will fry from shitty Chinese chargers or some other voltage spike on the magsafe.

ID0R comes from AMON and AMON is an current sense output from <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fails ASD -- ID0R & IG3C?
threads.message: Awesome, thanks Duke! That helps me a lot.
